plist.p: Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I would like to welcome you all to the telephone conference of BMW AG on the Second Quarter 2012. With me today are Dr. Norbert Reithofer, Chairman of the Board of Management of BMW AG; and Dr. Friedrich Eichiner, our CFO.

First, Mr. Reithofer will give you all an update on the business performance during the first six months of the year. Mr. Eichiner will then take you through our financial results for the second quarter and half year. Afterwards, we will have time for a Q&A session.
Mr. Reithofer, please go ahead.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. The BMW Group continues its success story. We continue to achieve profitable growth. We are working hard to meet the challenges of our industry. We are making great progress in developing the mobility of the future.

We had a strong second quarter, with a new record performance. In terms of sales, it was the strongest quarter in the history of the BMW Group, over 475,000 units sold. In terms of revenues, it was the strongest quarter in the history of the BMW Group, €19.2 billion. Group EBIT was again more than €2 billion. The EBIT margin in the Automotive Segment was 11.6%.

We deliver on our promises. That's what our customers expect and that's what BMW Group stakeholders expect as well. We continue to benefit from our Strategy Number ONE, our strong brands and our attractive products and services.
According to a study carried out by the Reputation Institute, the BMW Group is the world's most reputable company, ahead of Google and Apple.

The annual survey carried out by Millward Brown consultants confirmed that BMW is the most valuable automotive brand in the world. At the Automobil Forum in Stuttgart, we received the OEM of the Future Award as the most future-oriented automobile company in the world.

There continues to be strong demand for our vehicles, for example, the BMW 1 Series and the X1; the new BMW 3 Series Sedan and the 3 Series Convertible; the BMW 5 Series and the X5; and the BMW 6 Series with the recently launched 6 Series Gran Coupé; all are leaders in their market segments. This is proof of the design, efficiency, and substance of our vehicles.

In the first half of the year, we sold over 900,000 BMW, MINI and Rolls-Royce cars. This too is a new record in the history of the company. But more than anything else, all these achievements are built on a strong financial foundation. This gives us the confidence and leeway to make the necessary investments for further growth and profitability in the future.

Ladies and gentlemen, automotive markets worldwide are becoming ever more heterogeneous. We had double-digit growth in the first half of the year in many growth markets, as well as in the large Asian regions and North and Central America. However, in Europe consumers are growing more hesitant. The automotive market is also experiencing the impact of the sovereign debt crisis and the euro crisis.

In spite of difficult prevailing conditions, our sales in Europe remain on the same level as last year. However, in some European countries, we too have sold considerably fewer vehicles in 2012 than last year. Here we have been affected by the tough market conditions.

In spite of these challenges, we stand behind Europe. Europe is the largest sales market for our company. We sell almost half of our vehicles here. It is home to all our brands: BMW, MINI and Rolls-Royce, as well as Husqvarna. We see no alternative to a common Europe with a single currency area. The euro has generated growth, employment and prosperity in this country. It has considerably strengthened the role of Europe as an economic power.
For this reason, we continue to call for decisive action on the part of the member states as well as long-term policies that strike a sensible balance between austerity and growth.

We also expect the markets to remain volatile because in other regions of the world too, there is a significant dampening of growth. Competition is becoming tougher. Risks are increasing rather than decreasing.

How are we reacting to these challenges? With flexibility and foresight in all our actions. We monitor developments on the markets very closely and adapt our production volume as needed. This supports our competitiveness and increases the attractiveness of our brands. For us, profitable growth takes priority. Our lean structures and flexible processes equip us well for future fluctuations.

In addition, we continue to strive for a balanced distribution in global sales. In the first half of 2012, the shares of sales in our largest individual markets, Germany, the U.S. and China was about equal. In absolute terms, China and the U.S. were our strongest markets.

The premium segment in China should continue to offer good growth opportunities in the future. This is why we are expanding our activities there. At the end of May, we opened a second plant in Tiexi together with our partner Brilliance China Automotive. Depending on demand, we can produce up to 400,000 units at the Shenyang site in the medium term. With the new BMW X1 and the long wheelbase version of the new BMW 3 Series Sedan, two real firsts for China are rolling off the production line in Tiexi.

Together with Brilliance, we will also be upgrading our engine production in China. The current engine production facility will be relocated to a new site next to our Tiexi vehicle plant and developed to achieve a capacity of 400,000 units a year in the mid-term.

But North America also remains a high potential market, thanks to its positive demographics. For this reason we are expanding our capacity at Spartanburg. Furthermore, this autumn, we are launching the new BMW 3 Series with xDrive as well as the BMW X1. Both vehicles will bring additional momentum. And this is what our customers worldwide can expect for the rest of 2012. The new BMW 1 Series three-door for the first time with xDrive, the new BMW 3 Series Touring and the ActiveHybrid 3, the revised BMW X1, our flagship, the new BMW 7 Series, the new BMW M6 Coupé. For the MINI brand, the special edition MINI Clubman. For Rolls-Royce, the Phantom Series II.

Backed by all these initiatives, we remain confident that we will achieve our targets for the 2012 financial year. At the same time, we are already looking far into the future. In 2016, we aim to sell over 2 million vehicles. To achieve this, we are creating the preconditions today.

To grow the MINI brand, we are further expanding our U.K. locations in Oxford, Swindon and Hams Hall. The planned investment through to 2015 has increased to a total of £750 million. This market -- this makes it very clear that the U.K. will remain the heart of the MINI brand in the long term. In addition, we are in negotiations with Dutch automotive manufacturer, NedCar, regarding future contract production. Our aim is to create more capacity while retaining high levels of flexibility and attractive production costs.

Ladies and gentlemen, politics currently influence the automotive industry more than almost any other industrial sector. The current EU Commission proposal envisages a reduction in average CO2 emissions from new vehicles to 95 grams per kilometer by 2020. This is a huge challenge.
Similar stipulations have been made for China and the U.S.

BMW Group vehicles in Europe today emit an average of 145 grams of CO2 per kilometer, that's 30% less than in 1995. That means we have done more than most other manufacturers. In spite of this, the reduction we and the entire industry now face are formidable. They require massive investment in new technologies. It is the greatest challenge the automotive industry has ever faced. We accept the challenge and continue to set ourselves high targets.

By 2020, we plan to halve the CO2 emissions of our worldwide vehicle fleet compared to the mid-1990s. To do this, we are taking two parallel approaches: evolution and revolution. The combustion engine will remain the domination drive type for the foreseeable future. Therefore, we will continue to develop them even further. With Efficient Dynamics, we are making our engines even more fuel-efficient while also lowering emissions. This is evolution.

But there is also another certainty. We need future technologies for the targets set, both by ourselves and by environmental policies; technologies such as Plug-in hybrids and e-cars. For us, these efforts also include sustainable production, the use of new materials, and innovative mobility services. This is revolution.

At the end of 2013, our BMW i models will go into series production. Both vehicles, the i3 and the i8, give an innovative face to the vehicle of the future. They are tailor-made electric-drive vehicles.

We manufacture both models here in Germany. The main production of these vehicles will occur at our Leipzig plant. Carbon parts for the body and important components for the electric drive will be produced at the Dingolfing and Landshut plants.

Two reasons drove us to make this decision. First, we can leverage and continue to develop our employees' many years of expertise. Second, we are making our contribution as a carmaker towards Germany becoming the global leader and worldwide driver of electric mobility. The automobile was invented in Germany. Many innovations led to its further development in Germany as well. It was the German premium car companies more than anyone else that made driving more modern, efficient, and safe.

Today, made in Germany is a seal of quality all over the world. It stands for engineering craftsmanship, reliability and innovation. End customers are willing to pay a higher price for this. We need to defend this leading position because Germany's advancement as a location for technology and innovation is mainly driven by those that create and produce four wheels. To do this, we need the right prevailing conditions, incentives, and stimulus, especially in the initial phase.

Helping electric mobility to make its breakthrough, this is and remains a joint effort. If we manage to make Germany a pioneer in electric mobility, everyone will benefit. The companies involved, Germany as a business location, and the people who live and work in this country.

Ladies and gentlemen, the challenges our sector faces are truly complex. It would not make sense to try to go it alone. This is why we cooperate with strong partners. Since March, we have been collaborating with the Toyota Motor Corporation to carry out fundamental research into lithium-ion battery technology. Both companies are innovation leaders, both companies set standards in terms of sustainable mobility.

In the future, we intend to collaborate even more closely. A memorandum of understanding has laid out the areas of interest, to develop powertrain electrification, to develop fuel cells, to carry out research in lightweight technology, and for future vehicle architecture.

Leading individual mobilities into a new age is a task both exciting and challenging. We strive to fulfill this task in a highly volatile environment. This requires all of our innovative energy. It requires initiative, stamina and discipline. It is a challenge similar to running a marathon. And you can't win a marathon simply by sprinting the last few meters.

This is why we continue to work for profitable growth. This is why we are setting the course today for the mobility of tomorrow. This is why we are responsible and sustainable in our actions. This is our way. This is the BMW way. Thank you for listening.
Thank you very much, Norbert Reithofer and now Friedrich Eichiner, please go ahead.
Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon from my side as well. The BMW Group had a successful second quarter as we continued to prepare for the future. Our profitability remains high.

For the first time, we generated revenues of more than €19.2 billon at Group level in the quarter. Our quarterly earnings before taxes totaled €1.98 billion and were therefore lower than the same quarter last year, which also included one-off effect in the amount of €464 million.
The first half-year of 2012 has been our best ever so far with respect to sales, revenues and adjusted for one-off effects with respect to earnings.

The BMW Group continues on its growth track. In the first half of 2012, we hired new staff. We are building up core expertise in our Automotive segment in the key future areas of lightweight construction and alternative drive trains.

Now, let's turn to the Automotive segment. We reported record deliveries of 475,000 vehicles in the second quarter. That growth was driven mainly by the new BMW 1 Series and new 3 Series Sedan. But also our X3 and X5, the 5 Series and the new 6 Series models were very well-received by our customers.

Our sales continued to develop positively worldwide. The growth came mainly from our two largest single markets, China and the United States, but also from many emerging markets in Asia, Central and South America.

On the other hand, the economic situation in Europe has further worsened. Our year-on-year sales are lower in a number of European markets. Like our peers, we are facing more competition in those countries as well.

Our sales rose by 5.4% globally. Thanks to higher unit sales, our segment revenues exceeded €17 billion for the first time. Volume growth and currency effects also had a positive impact on segment earnings. We achieved an EBIT in the Automotive Segment of €2.02 billion in the second quarter. Our profitability remains high, 11.6% for both the quarter and the half year.

As previously announced, we also made up-front investments in future projects, in new technologies and the development of new business fields that will contribute to value creation over the long term. We need these investments in lightweight construction, alternative drive trains and mobility services to maintain our leading position going forward.

We are also systematically preparing the BMW Group to face changing mobility requirements and stricter CO2 regulations. Over the full year, we will invest around €1 billion of additional future investments into these areas.

The Automotive segment generated a strong operating cash flow and a free cash flow of €2.5 billion in the first six months. We expect this positive trend to continue throughout the rest of the year. We are still aiming for a free cash flow of more than €3 billion.

Ladies and gentlemen, our Financial Services segment continues on its growth track. Financial Services profited from a sales growth in the second quarter. The segment is still reaping the benefits of the more defensive residual values we set in previous years and the low volume of off-lease vehicles.

Financial Services concluded more than 346,000 leasing and financing contracts with retail customers in the second quarter. This represents a year-on-year increase of 10%. The main gains were in Europe, Middle East and Asia Pacific regions. The growth in Europe is mainly due to the acquisition of ING Car Lease. At the end of the second quarter, the total number of contracts in place had reached 3.69 million. This also includes ING Car Lease contracts.

Our fleet management company, Alphabet, has pushed ahead with the integration of ING Car Lease. The process has now been completed in a number of European markets such as the Netherlands, Spain and Belgium. Alphabet continues to expand market position. This subsidiary is now the fourth largest European fleet management company.
The BMW Group once again had access to attractive financing conditions on the international financial markets. This also benefited our financial services business.

Financial Services generated a pre-tax profit of €431 million in the second quarter. This includes a positive one-off effect of €35 million from end-of-lease business. Year-on-year earnings were lower overall because of the one-off effect of €379 million reported last year. However, adjusted for this one-off effect, segment earnings were around 10% higher than last year.

The Financial Services segment provided leasing or financing for 38.7% of new BMW Group vehicles in the second quarter. This rate is slightly lower than last year. This is due to China's rapidly growing market and the fact that the penetration rate is still relatively low in China. The risk situation remained largely unchanged in the second quarter. As expected credit risks were stable, although the situation in Southern Europe is still difficult. We do not expect to see any improvement in this area in the short term.

In addition, the residual values of our off-lease vehicles remained stable in the second quarter. Used-car prices have weakened somewhat in a number of European markets, especially in Southern Europe. We also expect to see a more volatile and more uneven market performance in the second half of the year, and we have accrued adequate risk provisions to cover potentially higher residual value losses.

Now let's move on to our Motorcycles segment. We delivered more than 37,000 BMW and Husqvarna motorcycles to customers in the second quarter. Sales volumes were lower than last year, owing to market developments in Southern Europe. We did, however, report growth in Brazil and the U.S., as well as Japan, France and Germany. Due to the lower volumes, revenues declined to €410 million in the second quarter. However, our EBIT at Motorrad at the end of the quarter was still higher at €48 million.

In the second half of the year, we expect to see an upward trend with the market launch of new BMW scooter models and the new Husqvarna models, the TR 650 Strada and the TR 650 Terra. This should have a corresponding impact on segment revenues and earnings.

Ladies and gentlemen, we remain cautiously optimistic about the second half of the year. The BMW Group has a young and attractive model lineup on the market. We expect sales to receive a further boost in the second half of 2012. Attractive new models like the new 7 Series Sedan, the 3 Series Touring and the 3 Series Sedan with xDrive will strengthen our sales volumes. The revised X1 will be coming onto the U.S. market and locally produced X1 models and the 3 Series Sedan Long-Wheelbase Version are now in showrooms in China.

We will benefit from this attractive product momentum over the coming months. The BMW Group is preparing intensively for the future. The upcoming BMW i models will revolutionize automotive engineering and the industry as we know it. This year, as previously announced, we will be making major upfront investments of an additional roughly €1 billion. We have the financial strength to shoulder these investments in our future.

The economic environment may worsen further in the second half of the year. In particular, we recognize two risks: a further weakening situation in Europe as well as potentially slower growth in China. Both could increase competition. Volatility in the markets is expected to remain high.

For that reason, we remain cautious and continue to monitor developments. If conditions change more than anticipated, we have the flexibility to respond decisively. All the same, even with countermeasures, we cannot completely rule out a possible negative impact on earnings.

We are maintaining our guidance, assuming conditions do not worsen significantly, and targeting record sales for all three premium brands. We are aiming for higher year-on-year earnings at group level and in the Automotive segment. The EBIT margin in the Automotive segment should be at the upper end of our 8% to 10% target range. We also intend to achieve returns on this scale on a sustained basis enhanced beyond the year 2012. However, depending on political and economic developments, the actual EBIT margin could end up being above or below the targeted range.

We expect to see a positive business development in the Financial Services segment despite higher volatility. Our contract portfolio should continue to grow. We are targeting a return on equity of more than 18%. We will maintain our solid, forward-looking financial management, focusing the BMW Group on long-term profitability and growth. The key objectives of our corporate strategy define the guidelines for our ongoing business development.
And now, ladies and gentlemen, we would be glad to take your questions. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Mr. Eichiner. Ladies and gentlemen, the line will shortly be open for questions, please wait for some technical advice.

We would also like to remind you that you may only raise two questions at a time. One moment, please, for the first question. The first question comes from Ms. Kristina Church from Barclays. Please go ahead, madam.

Yes. Thank you for taking my questions. Firstly, my question, I think the market is, obviously, nervous about the pricing environment particularly in Europe. And I know you gave some guidance on the press call this morning that in the quarter, your pricing was down 150 basis points. That seems to be a little worse than some of your peers, from what they've been reporting. Are you seeing a situation where your incentives are higher than peers? And how do you expect that to play out in the second half of the year?
And then my second question is on your €1 billion increased spending on technologies. I'm just wondering how that progresses.
Kristina, sorry, could you speak a little bit slowlier?

Sorry. The second question was on your €1 billion increased spending this year. I was just wondering how that progressed sequentially. If you could give a little update on how much of it has already been spent in the first half? How much is still to come in the second half and also whether we should expect any more incremental increases in 2013? Thank you.
Thank you very much, Kristina. This question will be answered by Mr. Eichiner. I think two parts of the question, first part was pricing.

Yes. First, let's talk about the pricing. I mean, you know about our original plan. The idea was to further improve pricing within the year 2012. Having said this, the improvement now is, from our perspective, not achievable as long as we see the prices in Europe especially in the Southern European markets but the situation is highly competitive.

And having said this, fortunately, in other big markets, it's fairly stable. So that's the case in the U.S. and that's -- for a certain extent, the case in China as well, so it's actually more or less a European problem. And as we all don't know how the competition will behave in the next couple of weeks and months, it's hard to predict how this will develop. Now, our assumption is that it should at least be stable, I mean in Europe and we see some chances to improve in other regions because we are now in a phase where all the new cars are coming to the markets in the new 3 Series Sedan, this new Series Sedan with all-wheel drive, the new Touring, those cars will all be available and from our perspective they have the potential to really make a difference. So, that's how we look at it and the numbers have been right. We had a hit of 150 basis points in the second half, where we still have to manage some run-outs, so -- on the 3 Series.

Now, your question about the future investments into new technologies. I mean the €1 billion number is what we are expecting overall for 2012 and now we spend nearly €400 million to €500 million in the first half of the year. And it's not a one-off within 2012. We expect the next two to three years that we have to stabilize this level of spendings in order to really manage the change in our industry.
Thank you.
Thank you, very much, Kristina. Next question, please.
The next question comes from Mr. Horst Schneider from HSBC. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes, good afternoon. Horst Schneider from HSBC. I would come back -- I would like to come back again to the pricing issue. What I do not yet understand fully is you increased your unit sales significantly, but at the same time you need to provide higher discounts. So, I want to know how important market share for you is and why are you focusing so much here on this market share issue?

And then the other question is this, I want to know to what extent you increase then the capacity in 2012? I think you have mentioned already that you expand capacity in Oxford, Spartanburg. You opened a plant in China but I would like to know to how many percent your capacity is increasing and finally in 2012 versus 2011 and I want to know what's the level of utilization in Q2 2012? Thank you.
Thank you very much, Horst. I think we'll start with Mr. Eichiner and then Norbert Reithofer about capacity and so on -- and market share, yes.

Your question about the pricing and -- well, the units increased and how we look at the context. I mean, first of all, we have a very heterogeneous picture around the world because the pressure, as I said, is in Europe and the growth, more or less is in China and the U.S. where we still have a fairly stable pricing. Well, that's one thing.

In Europe where the market is flat and in some countries, we have – we really see a recession like in Spain or in Italy. That's where the competition is. That's where the hard competition is and that's where the pricing is really getting tough.

And you should keep in mind, we cannot let go of the volume completely out of a profitability reasons because we have a dealer network there and we have to make sure that the dealer network really survives in a crisis like this and that is a reason why we think we have to maintain a certain momentum when it comes down to the market share development.

But haven't you said some time ago, it's better to sell one unit less than necessary? So you want to adopt to the old BMW pricing policy and now I get the impression that that is -- that cannot be the case anymore?

That's -- I would not say that this cannot be the case. I think we have to recognize that in markets like Spain and Italy, we have a very difficult situation, right. That's not normal. In a normal market like the U.S., we are behaving like this. Actually, we could sell more cars in the U.S., and -- but we didn't do so, that's why our pricing is stable, our residual values are stable, used car prices is improving, but that's a normal situation, how we want to see it.

But this is not something we can generate in those markets in the Southern part of Europe. It's -- because the market dropped so heavily. If you compare to 2007, it's more than 50% in Spain, for example. And as I said, there is another job we have to do -- in the midterm, we have to stabilize our dealer network and in order to stabilize, he needs to sell some cars, otherwise, he will die. And that's what we don't let go.
Okay.
Thank you very much, Mr. Eichiner. And now, Mr. Reithofer to capacity and market share.

I mean, our capacity utilization at existing plants is still on a high level. Why? I mean, you have to have in mind that we are in the pre-launch phase of a couple of new products, for example, a new BMW Touring as Mr. Eichiner already said. We are in the launch phase of the 6 Series Gran Coupé, 3 Series Sedan, with all-wheel drive, xDrive, how we call it, and then these vehicles are due for the second half of the year, especially, I mean, Mr. Eichiner mentioned it in the U.S., from September -- on September, October, November, December. And -- but I would like to add to what Mr. Eichiner said, I mean, our dealer stock in the United States is you can say, empty, flat. So that means we think that we have opportunities in the U.S. in the second half of the year and with the availability of the cars as well. And as I said, we have still a high capacity utilization at our existing plants and again, why?

I mean, you have to have in mind last year, more or less, 1.65 million, 1.66 million cars produced and this year we said, we will produce more than last year with more or less the same production network.
So what was the level of utilization in Q2?
100%. And total capacity grows by how many percent, 2012 versus 2011?

I mean, if you see couple of examples of important plants, I mean, in Spartanburg, we are more or less on a level of 300,000 units and we will not be able to produce more if then we talk about 5,000 units but not more. So in China, we are in the middle of the launch phase of our new plant in Tiexi. We will not have the full capacity for the year 2012. Well, that means we are in launch phases of new plants, Spartanburg, we are, let me use the word, we are chock-a-block full at the moment.

Mr. Eichiner mentioned especially if we have in mind the X3, we could sell more X3s. We cannot produce them because we have not enough capacity. So if I see that the German plants like Leipzig, like Dingolfing, Regensburg or Munich. They are all in the middle of the launch phase of our new 3 Series products, 1 Series products. And as I've said, the new products will be available in the second half of the year, especially the all-wheel drive versions, so -- and as I've said high utilization of capacity at the moment.
Thank you.
Thank you very much, Horst Schneider. Next question, please.
The next question comes from Mr. Arndt Ellinghorst from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes, good afternoon, everyone. It's Arndt Ellinghorst, Credit Suisse. And I have two questions. The first one is on China and CO2 regulation. Could you share your thoughts on the pending implementation of new CO2 regulation in China, please? And especially, if you could focus on the potential implications for vehicle imports and also the timing of an implementation of these new targets.

And the second question is, I guess, you're getting that on all the calls, your excess liquidity. Has anything changed with respect to your strategy or your view on how BMW will be dealing with excess liquidity moving forward? Could you update us with your thoughts, please? And could you please talk about – still, again the strategy on the ongoing dividend and potentially a special dividend? Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Arndt Ellinghorst. Now, I think we'll start with the second part of your question and with Mr. Eichiner.

Well, I mean, in the market situation we are in actually, our view is that we should move forward with the liquidity cover that should be at least between €8 billion and €10 billion. I mean, that's -- from our perspective something we need also in order to protect our rating. This is of utmost importance and we all experienced in 2008 how quickly the capital market could change and this would be something that would support our performance going forward. So that's the view on that.

Our dividend payment, I mean we paid out the €1.5 billion for 2011. You know our view has not changed. The range is 30 -- between 30% and 40%. A payout ratio that's still our target and we would like to deliver on this. And having said this, please keep in mind as we disclosed already, our CapEx will have to increase because now we have to protect and bring forward future investments for lightweight construction, electrification, new models in order to support our growth path and this will definitely have an influence on that CapEx side as well though. That is something we have to face for the next couple of months and maybe for the next three years.
Thank you very much Mr. Eichiner. So the second part of your question about CO2 in China and the development, Mr. Reithofer.

I mean as you know, the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has provided the automobile industry with a draft of the accounting rules for fuel efficiency in passenger vehicles in China from 2012 to 2015.

I mean, Mr. Ellinghorst, I'll make it really short and simple. What we have to achieve in 2015, is 5 – is 6.9 liters per 100 kilometers and further into the future, we have to achieve 5.9 liters per 100 kilometers.

At the end, what does it mean? It means China is no exception anymore as it comes to fuel efficiency, the rules and regulations are as tough as in Europe and as tough as in the United States of America. It means, all over the world, we are more or less faced with the same challenges and I can only say what Mr. Eichiner mentioned several times, what does it mean for the next couple of years. It means we need more research and development to achieve all these challenges lying ahead of us.
So -- and as I said, China more or less on the same track like Europe and the U.S. That is what it means. 6.9 liters and further down the road, 5.9 liters, average for the fleet in China.

And Dr. Reithofer, for your -- referring to your knowledge of the situation. Is there a risk that China comes up with a separate regulation for vehicle imports and that this emission footprint, if you call it, can potentially not be pooled with the locally manufactured cars, is there is such a risk?

I would not call it a risk. It is a possibility that it can happen. But at the moment, we are still -- how should I call it, can I call it -- still in a negotiation phase. It is a possibility, but we are still in a negotiation phase. Of course, our preferred solution is for imported cars and for locally produced cars, same rules and regulations.
Is there any view on the timing of this regulation?
Not at the moment. It's too early.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Arndt Ellinghorst. Next question please?
The next question comes from Mr. Christian Breitsprecher from Macquarie. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi, good afternoon. It's Christian Breitsprecher from Macquarie. I'm struggling a bit with your -- on the one hand guidance for the margin and at the same time all the positives that you're telling us for the second half.

With regard to pricing, you said that you suffered 150 basis points negative pricing in the second quarter. I guess that's seen off of the -- for the whole Automotive segment but you're telling us that on the second half, the pricing should be more or less stable versus the second quarter, so no further deterioration.

At the same time, you're telling us a lot about the positives coming with the 3 Series Touring and so on and xDrive models in the fourth quarter. Nevertheless, your guidance implies an EBIT margin in the Automotive segment of less than 10% in the second half.

Can you explain a little bit more how these two things are fitting together? And is it really just all the expenses for new projects and R&D that's driving down your margin assumption for the second half? Thank you so much.

Well, just to make my point absolutely clear. I said no further deterioration, but no further deterioration would mean that we would have to consider that the pricing will be not as good as the year before because I'm talking from the actual level of pricing and this actual level is 100 basis points, 150 basis points below the level we've seen last year, right. So and that's the level we expect to continue just to -- only to make that clear.

I don't think that we should expect further acceleration in the wrong direction, so further hit on the pricing, but as I've said, the situation we have now is possibly stable. And we need the new products in the market to maintain that level. That's a few especially in the European markets. So the positive influence of the new C Series should compensate further pricing pressure that is expected and enable us to keep it at the level we see it in the second quarter. So that's our view on that.

And having said this, in addition to the pricing, we have to consider that the cost will increase in the second half, two reasons. First is another €500 million to €600 million for future investments as we explained, will -- as a part of the €1 billion, we discussed already. And then normally, we always have a kind of a seasonality in the fourth quarter where all the year-end bills will be paid and so that is always a kind of hockey stick effect on the cost side in the fourth quarter that we have to consider as well.
Okay. Thank you very much, Christian Breitsprecher. Next question, please?
The next question comes from Mr. Jochen Gehrke from Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead, sir.
